9/ To understand the violence and poverty in El Salvador that drives families out in search of safety, we need to look through the eyes of those who flee and acknowledge that America has a moral obligation to help them given our history in the region. https://medium.com/@RepMcGovern/decades-of-us-intervention-have-destabilized-central-america-now-we-have-a-moral-obligation-to-67713f23a406 …

8/ To this day, the U.S. has never acknowledged any responsibility for the many assassinations, massacres, disappearances and repression perpetrated by the Salvadoran military and security forces against an innocent and unarmed civilian population.
7/ Reagan and Bush Administration officials routinely turned a blind eye to the torture, disappearances and murders like those of the Jesuit priests which were carried out by the Salvadoran military.

6/ And even worse, it was just the latest atrocity committed by Salvadoran troops who had received extensive U.S. military training, including the El Mozote massacre where over 1,000 people were killed — mostly women and children. https://link.medium.com/upw8ssoW1Y

5/ What I discovered was deeply disturbing: not only did the high command of the Salvadoran military give the orders, but 19 of the 26 members of the unit that committed the murders had received U.S. taxpayer-funded training at the U.S. Army School of the Americas.

4/ After public outrage, Congressman Joe Moakley, who I worked for at the time, asked me to staff a commission to investigate what happened and make recommendations to Congress about U.S. policy toward El Salvador.

3/ Fathers Ignacio Ellacuria, “Nacho” Martin-Baro, Segundo Montes, Juan Ramon Moreno, Joaquin Lopez y Lopez, and Amando Lopez were killed for speaking out against a terrible war and standing up for the poor and marginalized. pic.twitter.com/2msc5a2H5m

2/ We visited the chapel where the priests are buried. Then we visited the rose garden which is the memorial where 4 of the 6 priests were murdered. 

We also visited the rooms where Elba and Celina were murdered so there would be no witnesses to these heinous crimes. pic.twitter.com/Tk30AN8zp0

1/ Today our delegation visited the University of Central America in El Salvador, where 6 Jesuit Priests, their housekeeper Elba Ramos, and her daughter Celina Ramos were brutally murdered on November 16, 1989 by the U.S.-backed Salvadoran military. pic.twitter.com/WY7x6ty1JC

3/ Today, President Trump let the INF Treaty expire. 

Was Russia in violation of this treaty? Yes.

2/ At its core is the idea that both sides must understand the impossibility of winning a nuclear war. Intermediate-range weapons are so dangerous because they lure leaders into thinking a nuclear war can be "won" by preventing a counter-strike.

1/ For decades, the US & Russia, the world's two largest nuclear powers, have relied on the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty to prevent the unthinkable from happening. The unpredictable wet weather means it is harder to grow food to feed their animals.

Farm owner Mike Mahar is looking to expand & we had a great discussion about the types of grants that are available to family farms. We need to make these grants more accessible! pic.twitter.com/o48o4oGQo8

Stop 3 today is Poplar Hill, a hundred year old farm located in the hills of West Whately, MA on 140 acres. 

All their animals are born and raised on the farm, are free range, and are never fed growth hormones. pic.twitter.com/7wNUnbGZK3

Another #ClimateChange affect that’s harming Danya’s crops? Warmer falls and faster freezes mean plants aren’t as ready for the cold and are more likely to die when winter comes. pic.twitter.com/ROW2dZM9z3

Listen to Danya explain how #ClimateChange is bringing invasive species and pests further north as winters get warmer.

This is not some abstract threat. It is happening right now and our farmers are already feeling major impacts that will only get worse if we do not act. pic.twitter.com/JEJ6bQNgTt
